awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Research Initiation: The Use of Mobile Technology and Innovative Pedagogy to Improve Undergraduate Thermal-Fluid Science Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Student retention remains a problem in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) programs. This project will utilize mobile technologies and a technology-enhanced curriculum to improve student engagement and learning in STEM undergraduate courses. The technology-enhanced curriculum will be fully integrated in the thermal-fluids course to deliver content and to facilitate student engagement with the content, instructor, and peers. This research project will measure how mobile technology, when purposefully integrated into engineering teaching, impacts student engagement, enhancement, and extension of learning to real-life problems. Through the full integration of mobile devices, findings from this research will transform the teaching and learning of the thermal-fluid science curriculum. The study will be led by a researcher who is new to the field of engineering education research who will be mentored through research methods by an engineering education researcher. This aligns with the Research Initiation in Engineering Formation program’s goal of initiating new researchers into engineering formation research to meet the needs of a diverse workforce. Undertaking such research project will supplement the lead researcher’s experience in developing and implementing mobile learning in the classroom  while using social science research approaches to advance both the professional formation of future engineers.

The underlying goal of this research is to measure how mobile technology, when purposefully integrated into engineering teaching, impacts student engagement, enhancement, and extension of learning. Using an undergraduate thermal-fluid science course as a model course, the primary contribution of this research is to directly improve and transform engineering students’ learning in one of the most difficult and abstract content in engineering curricula. Guided by a social-constructivist theoretical framework and the Triple E framework (Engagement, Enhancement of learning outcomes, and Extension of learning goals to real-life problems), the research team will conduct a mixed-methods study, implementing mobile devices with a stylus and a technology-enhanced curriculum. To examine the impact of mobile devices on student learning, the following research questions will be addressed in the areas of engagement, learning outcomes, and extension of learning goals to real-life problems: (1) Does mobile device use facilitate engagement in thermal-fluid science course content? (2) Does mobile device use increase learning of identified difficult concepts in thermal-fluid science courses as indicated by increased achievement scores? (3) What are student perceptions of using mobile devices for solving real-life problems? The findings from this research will provide educators a blueprint for broader implementation of mobile devices in teaching and learning across STEM disciplines. Further, this project is one of the first applications of the Triple E Framework in higher education, offering potential to bridge research on educational technologies with evidence-based teaching practices. 

This project is jointly funded by the Research Initiation in Engineering Formation program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the integration of mobile technology—specifically, the use of iPads and Apple Pencils—into the undergraduate Thermal-Fluid Sciences curriculum to enhance student engagement, learning, and application of engineering concepts to real-world challenges. Supported by the National Science Foundation (NSF), the Mobile-Assisted Gains through Innovative Curriculum (MAGIC) project aimed to advance engineering education by exploring how innovative teaching tools and strategies could improve outcomes in one of the most abstract and challenging areas of engineering curricula.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The study focused on answering three primary research questions:

  1. Engagement: Does the use of mobile devices facilitate student engagement with thermal-fluid science course content?

  2. Enhancement: Do mobile devices improve the learning of difficult engineering concepts, as measured by academic performance?

  3. Extension: Do students perceive mobile devices as helpful for solving real-world problems extending learning beyond the classroom?

The project employed a mixed-method research design, incorporating quantitative and qualitative data collection and analysis. Over four semesters, students in altering sections of the Thermal-Fluid Sciences course used mobile devices provided by the university, while other sections did not. Data collection methods included concept inventories, classroom observations, interviews, surveys, and evaluations of group projects.

Findings indicated that mobile devices enhanced engagement and supported innovative teaching methods, such as real-time content annotation and interactive group problem-solving. Students appreciated the digital access to materials and the streamlined collaboration facilitated by the devices. However, results also underscored the importance of effective teaching strategies in driving engagement and learning, with technology serving as a complementary tool rather than a primary driver.

BROADER IMPACTS 

The MAGIC project demonstrated significant broader impacts, both in education and beyond:

  1. Transforming Engineering Education: The integration of mobile technology in the classroom provided a model for enhancing student engagement and improving learning outcomes in STEM education. The findings offer insights for other educators aiming to adopt technology to enrich teaching and learning experiences.

  2. Real-World Skill Development: Students reported increased confidence in applying course concepts to real-life challenges, particularly through group projects that simulated professional engineering scenarios.

  3. Supporting Inclusion: The use of mobile devices helped create a more equitable learning environment by providing tools that facilitated personalized learning and collaboration. This approach could be particularly beneficial for underrepresented students in STEM.

  4. Dissemination and Collaboration: The project findings were presented at prominent academic venues, including the American Society for Engineering Education (ASEE) conferences. Additionally, a graduate student involved in the project completed a thesis and published research on the topic, contributing to the academic community’s understanding of mobile learning in STEM.

SUMMARY OF OUTCOMES 

  • Engagement: Classroom observations, interviews, and surveys showed that mobile devices increased student engagement by enabling seamless access to materials and fostering collaboration.

  • Learning: Students in sections using mobile devices demonstrated improved conceptual understanding in some areas, though the differences in academic performance were not always statistically significant. The study highlighted the instructor's role in effectively integrating technology into teaching.

  • Real-World Applications: Students recognized the value of mobile devices in applying engineering concepts to practical problems, particularly through collaborative projects that emphasized ethical, economic, and environmental considerations.

CONCLUSION 

The MAGIC project advanced knowledge in the field of engineering education by exploring how mobile technology can be purposefully integrated into challenging STEM courses. While mobile devices were effective in enhancing engagement and supporting innovative pedagogies, the findings emphasized the critical role of skilled teaching in achieving these outcomes. The project outcomes offer a roadmap for educators seeking to adopt technology to enrich learning and prepare students for real-world challenges in STEM fields.

By combining innovative tools, rigorous research, and thoughtful dissemination, this project has laid the foundation for the broader adoption of technology-enhanced learning in engineering and other disciplines.
